reviewText:
There's just not enough here to recommend this game.

You fight monters, but the fights are not interesting.  You can choose what part of the monster to attack, but the only difference is damage vs. chance-to-hit, which is not an interesting choice.
There is crafting, but it is not interesting.  You can combine items that give you health or hunger into items that give you (more) hunger or health.  You can create weapons, but the only difference between weapons is the damage.  (Also the UI for crafting is extremely lacking)
There are simply not enough strategic choices.  You either walk down to the next floor, or check out the two rooms on this floor.  When you enter a room, either you loot all the stuff it in, or fight an enemy and then loot all the stuff in it.  Every floor is the same.
I made it to floor 60 on my first game, and was really bored the entire time, so I let myself die and started over hoping the the first game was just a tutorial.  Unfortunately, it's wasn't.

On a more positive note, the art was decent, the voice acting was good, and the programming was well-done (the game is not buggy).  Unfortunately it's just not fun.  I'd wait until this game is in an indie bundle if you want to give it a shot.

reviewText:
The main problem with this game is there is too much of not enough.

The game has turn based combat - but there is barely any strategy to it other than picking which dice to roll. There is nothing actively happening in these fights to make the player feel interested. All you feel is frustration over your health ticking down when there is nothing you can actively do inside or outside the combat system to better yourself.

The game has RPG stat elements  - but they are probably the lamest, most simplistic I've ever seen. Leveling a character is so linear and obvious that it shouldn't make a player scratch his head any longer than 5 seconds to figure out what path to take (largely dependant on what weapon the game's RNG decides to give you early on). There isn't even any defense ratings for character or monsters, making the whole weapon/damage system feel hugely simplistic and unrewarding.

There's a crafting system - it's pretty bread and butter. The actual items you can create and variety isn't too bad really. But the way the game plays out just makes it another aspect that falls to the side as unrewarding, plagued by RNG happenstance, and rather pointless. It's true you will need to use it to some extent to make it to the bottom, but I doubt you would need to invest in much, which is good considering there is no active way to get materials you really need. In other survival games, you have areas that have greater or exclusive chances to wield certain items. This game it's all at the drop of a hat, and it completely makes the player feel void of any real sense of achievement, because they never feel like they are actively surviving.

The premise of the game sounds super neat - but in reality it's such a hollow rendition of what the game promises on paper. You have to escape a hotel from the 100th floor and get to the bottom. When you realize that each floor has two... yes, two rooms on each floor, I think that's when it kicks in how lazy, barebones and unadventurous this game really is. I'm also not sure what hotels these developers have been to, but this building barely even qualifies to be a crappy highrise in Newham.

In the end , this needed to be fleshed out, in all areas, by a factor of 10. The price of admission makes it clear that they're not even shy (or are perhaps ignorant) to have made such a minimalist and lacking game.

reviewText:
Skyhill is great. It's a roguelike, 2D, turn based, dungeoneering type thing. You're a dude who booked himself into a VIP room in a hotel, then an apocalypse happened. You have to fight your way from the top floor to the bottom floor trying to maintain your health and keep your hunger levels down along the way. You can use the hotel lift to get back up to your Room, where you can sleep to heal if you're running low on medical items and make other improvements to the room that allow to to craft more complex foods (which replenish your hunger by more points) and build more complex weapons and medical supplies.

The mechanics reward careful thinking and efficient resource allocation but the turn based combat does involve an element of luck. You might not always find good food or medical items and you can't rely on anything. Even on the easy difficulty it's a fairly challenging game. I think it'll take me a few attempts to get much further than floor 50.

I did get my key for this game free in a giveaway the developer did on the fly during one of Dodgers Twitch streams because Dodger was playing Skyhill at the time. I have to say, the devs are really nice and I'm so happy this game turned out to be a lot of fun.

reviewText:
TL; DR version:
I am keenly aware that Skyhill does enough right to merit a recommendation. However, I am going to give it a CAREFUL recommendation at the current stage and the current price. 15€ is a tad high for what this game is. It needs some more content, methinks... For now, anything from 33% off or more would make it an easy buy, as you will absolutely get your money's worth.

Longer version:

In Skyhill, you are a businessman on a short trip who decides to rest in the best Suite of a large luxurious 100-story hotel during a time of war. During his stay, one of the warring sides (and obviously the losing one), the Confederates, launches a biological weapon at your location that turns everyone into mutants or zombies. You survive, but soon the hunger drives you out and you need to find a way to survive and go to the ground using all the resources you can fnd at your disposal, or die trying in this post-apocalyptic rogue-lite game.

So let's take a look at what the game does well, and what poorly.

The GOOD:

1. Lots of rooms to explore and loot - you will have over 190 rooms to explore and loot throughout your adventure, contaning everything from food to stuff you can use as weapons or consumables, or to save for later for crafting.
2. Upgradable stations - in short, your suite is your fortress. You can improve it in a number of ways. You can create better weapon building or cooking stations, fortify the door and fix up the bed so you can rest better and regain health.
3. Lots of items to craft and use - the amount of weapons to make and use in combat is amazing - and it pays to note that some weapons can also be upgraded to better versions by using the core weapon(s). The devs really went overboard with the craftables be it weapons, food, or stuff you can make on the fly like bandages and medicine. The system really forces you to think whether you should use a certain item or save it for later. And about that...
4. Decisions you make when it comes to craftables matter - being a rogue-lite with a randomly generated loot, it is always a huge decision whether to use a certain item or not, as god knows whether you'll find another one of those. In the end, when all falls into place, knowing that you've made the correct decisions is extremely satisfying.
5. An RPG system that ties well into the weapon crafting - you have 4 skills that can be improved throughout the adventure and govern various types of combat - strength (the ability to wield powerful heavy weapons that do the most damage), speed (the ability to wield fast weapons and also get faster with improved chance for 2 action per turn), dexterity (the ability to wield weapons based on agility and dodge in combat) and accuracy, which improves you chance to hit.
6. Starting and unlockable perks that make your playthroughs vary a lot  - from the ability to always go first to being extra lucky or have an extra ration or a medkit in your backpack, picking different perks during the various playthroughs will let you experience the game from a different perspective.
7. Great combat - as a consequence of 3-6, the combat in this game is really good, and the outcome of a fight always ties into every decision you have made so far, be it wrong or right. And talking about decisions, you can also manually target various parts of the enemy body to inflict more damage at a higher chance to miss or less damage with a higher chance to hit. Just remember to run away when things go bad... No need to die heroically when you can still live to fight another day.
8. Mini quests to keep you occupied while exploring - from finding keys to open various rooms to discovering cell phones with messages on them, you always have someting to look for as you search the floors of the hotel.
9. Good game aesthetic for a rogue-lite - while I wouldn't put that on the top of the list, I still appreciate how the game looks for a 2-D one.
10. Great replayability - the combination of perks, stuff you find, character build you make, and the little quests always make for a different experience the next time you boot up the game.

And now let's take a look at the BAD:

1. To counter #10 of the GOOD, even though a good number of parts of the game feel differently based on the perks, skills, weapons and stuff you pick, you ultimately do the same thing over and over again - find loot, craft, eat food, make weapons, open rooms, fight, survive, and hopefully get out of the hotel alive. I, personally, finished the game 3 times in my 5 hours of play, and sadly, I couldn't shake that feeling upon leaving the hotel...
2. The RNGesus can make or break your game, unless you like to invest heavily in accuracy so that you wont miss too often. Or, of course, you get stuff that doesn't fit your character build at all... Or not enough food or medicine... or other stuff... you get the point.
3. You can lose games through no fault of your own - in true rogue-lite fashion, victory through correct actions is not guaranteed. You may not find the stuff you need to get you set up properly, or you can get attacked way too often and die, and so on and so forth.
4. I didn't exactly enjoy the music... while it undoubtedly fits the whole experience, I eventually muted it and played my own.
5. Once you unlock all the perks, dying does feel like a true game over - until you unlock every perk, dying is ok and always lets you try something new the next time around. But once you unlock everything, dying is just that - death, game over, force restart.

Conclusion:

I am keenly aware that Skyhill does enough right to merit a recommendation. However, I am going to give it a CAREFUL recommendation at the current stage and the current price. 15€ is a tad high for what this game is. It needs some more content, methinks...For now, anything from 33% off or more would make it an easy buy, as you will absolutely get your money's worth. Why?

Easy. If you are a huge loot hoarder like me, like exploring, improving and seeing the stuff you do matter, this game is absolutely the right one for you. However, if you get easily irritated by loss, bad dice rolls, or games that expect you to play them for a bit to learn their quirks, I would stay away from it.

You pretty much get what the trailer shows, a survival game where you travel down a hotel, scavenging supplies, building weapons, upgrading safehouse and repeatedly dying. The game has some replayability thanks to unlocking perks which give you a special start bonus, though some of those are near useless while others superior over everything else.

Combat is simplistic and turn based, only real option being deciding if it's worth the risk to trade blows or retreat, it could do with more options. It's the stats, equipment and some dice rolling that decides if you win for the most part. Some fights are unavoidable too, while others can be bypassed entirely or occur in side areas.

The game is randomly generated which adds to replayability but also makes obtaining the components for your desired weapon that much harder.

And there's multiple endings too, if you're engaged enough to want to look for them. All in all, if the trailer interested you, go for it.

reviewText:
The first video advertising Skyhill on the Steam store page makes it seem a lot more fun than it actually is.  I expected a game that would make me think more about the choices I had to make to survive.  I expected more dynamic gameplay (especially from a roguelike).  I expected more replay value (especially from a roguelike).

In reality:

* The gameplay is repetitive.
* In most cases, the decisions you make are obvious.
* The fact that it's a roguelike does not make one playthrough that much different than another playthrough, which means ...
* The replay value is next to nil.

I guess the one positive thing about the game is that the crafting is kind of interesting.  However, you can only perform most of the crafting on the top floor, and, at some point, you're likely to be low enough on food and far enough from a working elevator that the cost of making your way to the top floor simply isn't worth it anymore, meaning better weapons, parts used to restore power to floors, etc. are not craftable for the rest of the playthrough.

2/10.

reviewText:
To be honest, I wasn't expecting anything great out of Skyhill. However, what I was met with turned out to be a fun and addictive rogue-like title with simple mechanics and a simple premise.

You're Perry Jason (yes, I know), and your main goal at this time is to get to the bottom of the Skyhill Hotel. You have 100 floors to traverse, and three rooms on each floor. The variety in items and monsters is very slim, but the amount of events that can occur and the highly likely event that the game will screw you over during a good run will keep you coming back for more.

Out of the nearly seven hours I've put into the game since its release, I have only been able to beat the game twice; both the alternate endings, I haven't even unlocked the original ending yet. I haven't even unlocked Hardcore mode at this point. So there's still quite a bit of replayability left.

The achievements add another element to the game which will elongate the experience for players. Feeling extra lucky? Try an all Vegan run! Hate your life? Beat the game on Hardcore! Super unlucky? Well there's achievements for those of you who can't stop dying.

Overall, Skyhill has been one of my favorite rogue-like experiences. I highly recommend it for fans of the genre, as it is challenging but you can take things at your own pace. Let's also not forget the crafting. If you're good at prioritizing your goods, you can come out of Skyhill with some pretty godly weapons; though remember, you can't take them to the next playthrough.

reviewText:
All you want to do is to have a quiet evening in a VIP room at the top of a hotel, and then someone had to go and bomb the city. Thankfully you have a room with a bio-shield that will block the harmful radiation or poison that is now spewing all over the town. There's only one problem, you see you're going to run out of food, and when you do that you are going to have to venture out. So you have to ask yourself one thing, can you make it out of the hotel alive?

In the game of SkyHill you are going to be forced with that very question. The thing is once you are out of your room, you might as well try to get out of the hotel. There is one slight problem though, you see the VIP room is on the top of the hotel, a hotel that just happens to have 100 floors, so to get out of there alive you are going to have to go all the way down.

There are two statistics that you will have to pay attention to ABOVE all else, and that is your Health and Hunger. If you let your health dip below zero, well then you are dead. If you let your hunger dip below zero, well your health starts taking a hit. So you will have to balance your food intake as well as your medicine intake. Don't take too much at any point, but don't take too little that you will fall prey to the monstrosities that now hide within the building.

There's not much I didn't like about this game. There's challenge galore, you will never play the same game twice as the building is randomized on every playthrough. I will tell you this, though, your hunger will slowly increase through EVERY room that you walk through, and it will greatly increase when you are trying to fix something without the correct materials.The good thing is that you there's only always 3 rooms to a floor. You have the stairway/elevator hall, and then a room to the left and right. Be careful when going anywhere in this game because enemies can appear in ANY of these rooms. Oh and on a side note don't get to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ when you discover that there are rooms that have nothing in them, or that appear to have something but turn out to be empty.

For the completionist out there one of the main reasons why you are going to continue to come back and play this game is that there are collectables hidden in the game, and of course you have to collect them all. For those who are just looking for a one run type of experience, I'm going to warn you now, even if you make it to the bottom and get an ending, you're probably going to want to play again just to see if that's the ending that will always happen.

So here's the deal, are you looking for a solid game that deals with mutated human beings, some of them that you hope you only see once in the game (I'm talking about the lady mutant, once you see her, you'll know you don't want to EVER see her again)? Are you looking for a game that has crafting of weapons, food, medical supplies, and upgrades to the crafting areas so that you have access to more stuff? Are you looking for a game that if you play your cards right you will HAVE TO play from start to finish? Well this is the game that you have to have on your radar. There's no other way to say it, this is a good game, and there's only 1 flaw that irks me to no end and that is that sometimes you consume more than 1 piece of food or medical supply when you are trying to decrease your hunger or heal yourself, but it doesn't happen all the time, and the way I played the game it actually was never truly a waste. So here's the score, this game gets a 9.3 out of 10.

This game is not bad. However, it is overpriced for what it is.

When you first start playing the game is fun, however after half an hour or so it quickly becomes repetitive and it will seem as if your success is very random and there is no real skill involved.

In fact this is not entirely true - to have any hope of completing the game you need to make good use of the crafting system and you need to be strategic to survive. Once you start paying attention to upgrading your room, crafting weapons and cooking food the odds start to shift in your favour and for me the game then became fun again.

Unfortunately you'll have to figure out most of this stuff for yourself as the tutorial is pretty lightweight  - I didn't realise until I'd played and died a few times that you could sleep, upgrade the bed and various other items in your room etc.

Once I started to formulate a strategy I did enjoy the game again - I think a lot of people give up before they ever reach this point though because the game doesn't really emphasise the importance of crafting, sleeping and so on. A lot of the perks actually make things worse too, which can be frustrating, so choose wisely.

Gameplay is based far too overtly around probability - I sort of didn't mind that but a lot of it is trying to be clever by offering perks that on the face of it sound good but aren't or vice-versa, which really is a way of making you die more often and lengthening the game. There are perhaps eight or ten different enemies and several of them are variations on the same creature.

Now I've beaten the game there's really no replay value left in it. For £5 or less I'd probably recommend it if you enjoy roguelite games - it will entertain you for a few hours if you don't get bored before the strategy elements start to crystallise. At over a tenner I'd save your money and wait for it to get cheaper.

Each floor has a lobby and 2 rooms.  The lobby can be the host of some nice goods like vending machines.  But they also hold power boxes that need to be repaired if the elevator is to reach any floor below that one(including the floor the power box is on).  The rooms can carry more resources than the lobbies and may hide subquests you can take on for extra experience.

But the mutants are in the building.  They want to kill you.  Take whatever weapon you can find(even if it gives less damage, it's better than going bare-fisted) and kill them.  You can let that weapon fly or go for a more 'aimed' approach.  But accuracy is vital.  Should you miss, death will be one step closer.  Once you have slain enough you will level up.  This will give you stat points that can give you an edge or make that weapon you are wielding a lot more potent than it is.

But remember: dying is normal.  As you die you will gain perks that can also give you a push to escaping Skyhill.  The passive has benefits but also have a cost.  For example: you can be impervious to food-poisoning but hunger will be much more lethal.  There are also active perks.  Some are single-use while others require you to wait before using again.

It's a good thing that home base is a VIP room.  Access to this allows you to upgrade various parts of the room.  Improve your workbench for better weapons.  That bed, as damaged as it is, can be turned into a five-star comfort.  That door doesn't look safe, but that can be alleviated.  Home cooking can be a dream come true if you bring the right components.

The graphics are simple but well designed.  Enemy animations to walking down the stairs in fast-forward.  The music also adds to the somber feeling of the game.

This is a lovely game.  If this interests you, but you are on the edge try the demo.

Each floor has a lobby and 2 rooms.  The lobby can be the host of some nice goods like vending machines.  But they also hold power boxes that need to be repaired if the elevator is to reach any floor below that one(including the floor the power box is on).  The rooms can carry more resources than the lobbies and may hide subquests you can take on for extra experience.

But the mutants are in the building.  They want to kill you.  Take whatever weapon you can find(even if it gives less damage, it's better than going bare-fisted) and kill them.  You can let that weapon fly or go for a more 'aimed' approach.  But accuracy is vital.  Should you miss, death will be one step closer.  Once you have slain enough you will level up.  This will give you stat points that can give you an edge or make that weapon you are wielding a lot more potent than it is.

But remember: dying is normal.  As you die you will gain perks that can also give you a push to escaping Skyhill.  The passive has benefits but also have a cost.  For example: you can be impervious to food-poisoning but hunger will be much more lethal.  There are also active perks.  Some are single-use while others require you to wait before using again.

It's a good thing that home base is a VIP room.  Access to this allows you to upgrade various parts of the room.  Improve your workbench for better weapons.  That bed, as damaged as it is, can be turned into a five-star comfort.  That door doesn't look safe, but that can be alleviated.  Home cooking can be a dream come true if you bring the right components.

The graphics are simple but well designed.  Enemy animations to walking down the stairs in fast-forward.  The music also adds to the somber feeling of the game.

This is a lovely game.  If this interests you, but you are on the edge try the demo.

reviewText:
This review was written for FREEDOM Community Gaming Collective[freedomcgc.com].
After checking into the hotel, I decide to watch a bit of television. My plan to unwind is abruptly cut short as the newscaster reports that the city has been attacked. I look out of my penthouse window and I can just see the first impact. A huge mushroom cloud appears on the horizon. It’s something we never expected would happen. Nuclear war. But it’s not just ordinary nuclear weapons. These bombs apparently contain biological agents that turn people into horrible mutant abominations. I try calling the cops, even the front desk. No reply. After a while, my food runs out and I realize that I have to leave this place if I want to survive. But I have also been hearing strange noises. I suppose it’s better to go out there and try to survive than die of starvation.

Skyhill is a 2D point-and-click game that places you in the aftermath of World War III. People have turned into mutants and your objective is to try to escape from the hotel. The problem is that you’re stuck in the penthouse of a hotel with 100 floors. And the elevator is out. You have to make your way down, floor by floor. The layout of each floor is exactly the same. The central area is reserved for the staircase and elevator with one hotel room to the left and another to the right. Your first priority is scavenging for food. The protagonist has a hunger bar and a health bar. You lose hunger points every time you move from one room to another. If your hunger bar goes all the way down, the health bar is next. And if that one hits zero, it’s game over.

The key to Skyhill is exploring rooms and picking up food and various items. Your penthouse acts a base of operations. You can return there whenever you want in order to craft or upgrade items. Every five to ten floors you will be able to fix a small section of the elevator. The elevator can take you back up to your penthouse or upper floors that you have already visited, but it won’t go down. You have to use the staircase and repair the elevator bit by bit until you reach the ground floor. You may be tempted to just go all the way down without exploring hotel rooms, but that won’t get you very far. You’ll either die of starvation or you’ll encounter a deadly mutant. Preparation is important.

As you gather various items, you will be able to use the workbenches in your penthouse and craft weapons, medkits, and other items. The crafting system is intuitive and easy to understand. You can also combine multiple pieces of food to prepare meals that provide more hunger points. You can also upgrade these workbenches in order to unlock more elaborate meals and weapons. If you’re running out of health and don’t have any means to heal yourself, you can use your bed and go to sleep. This will exchange hunger points for health points. Just be sure that you have food to restore those hunger points. Upgrading the bed will make it more efficient. Sometimes you will be awaken by nightmares or strange noises, which will affect how many health points you were able to restore. To mitigate this effect, you can choose to upgrade your doors, so you can feel perfectly safe while sleeping.

Once you enter a room occupied by a mutant, a fight will ensue. The combat system is turn-based. You can just click on the mutant for a basic hit or you can go into the battle screen. This will enable you to choose where you want to hit the mutant. For example, hitting the head will deal more damage, but the chances of missing are significantly increased. That’s pretty much all there is to it, the combat system is very simple. That can actually be said about all of the game’s systems. The exploration, level design, character upgrade system (each level you can choose to upgrade damage, speed, dexterity, and accuracy), crafting system, combat system – it’s all relatively basic. However, I still found the game rather enjoyable. Roaming through the hotel, looking for that one elusive item you need to craft that badass weapon is actually pretty interesting.

After each playthrough you will unlock passive and active perks that you can enable at the start of a new playthrough. Choosing a different combination of perks does provide a slightly more different experience, but after several playthroughs, the simplicity of the design and systems in place is going to start to wear very, very thin. The truth is that the design and gameplay simply cannot sustain more than a few playthroughs. You will not only feel like you’ve seen everything there is to see, you will actually see it all. There are three different endings to shoot for and that is where you will have completely exhausted the content of this game. I have to say that the endings are rather unexpected and well done. However, as everything else in the game, the storytelling is rather rudimentary and not particularly involving.

Skyhill sports a very nice, clean art style. The interface is also simple and intuitive. You always know what is going on around you and what items you are missing for that weapon that you want to craft. The sound design isn’t that noteworthy. There’s barely any music to speak of and the sound effects are entirely unimpressive.

This is a slightly odd call to make because I did enjoy Skyhill. This is a good foundation. But it needs to be built upon. There is simply no denying the fact that the design and gameplay systems are too basic. Roguelikes need to support many playthroughs, all of which should provide a different experience. Skyhill simply doesn’t succeed in this task. However, it is still an enjoyable romp while it lasts.

6 OUT OF 10 (FAIR)

reviewText:
Review copy provided by developer

Described by the creators as a point and survival game Skyhill sees your character survive a nuclear apocalypse and after eventually running out of food and supplies having to venture out from his protected penthouse on the 100th floor with the intention of reaching the ground.

The main mechanics of the game are managing both your health and hunger as you travel down each stairwell with the option of investigating both rooms on each floor. Every move you make uses up one point of hunger so sensibly navigating the games rooms is essential.
Another key mechanic is the games combat. As you meet an enemy you must select your weapon and then choose which body part you are going to attack. Different body parts have a higher percentage chance of missing but equally harder to hit parts do significantly more damage. This turns the combat into a logic puzzle as you get further down the building and the enemies get harder and harder.

In order to help manage your hunger and health there is a well fleshed out crafting system to allow you to craft food, resources and weapons as well as a level up system with a simple set of stats you can add to.

As you descend you unlock access to the elevator that allows you to travel back up to your penthouse and improve food and weapons. It also becomes important to use you Penthouse to sleep and regain life especially on the higher difficulties as enemies become harder and first aid kits become scarcer. This works by increasing your health but reducing your hunger bar meaning you are generally starving when you awake.

There are a few issues I have with the game to do with balance. I will say that with each play through there is an active and passive ability to help you that you can choose at the start. Some are more helpful than others with a particular overpowered favorite of mine being Bulimia which reduces your hunger loss by 50% but makes it possible to take damage when you eat. Equally there are a few weapons that are easier to gain than others that are very powerful the clock work axe being a good example of this.

Now I am not usually a fan of roguelikes but there really is something about Skyhill that grabbed me and would not let me go. As you progress you are drip fed storied through articles you find as well as some key bits of information about side plots that only become apparent through multiple playthroughs and alternate endings.

Having completed the game relatively easily on easy and just about on normal the hard is proving difficult and the currently locked nightmare mode is about as far from seeming possible to me right now as it could be.

All in all Skyhill is a very original roguelike game that is different from anything I have played before and is well worth your time. Games take a reasonable length and it never outstays its welcome with subsequent playthroughs drip feeding you more and more of the games story.

Cannot recommend it enough though, fantastic game.

reviewText:
Sky Hill is great for a lot of reasons, but it has a few things I would like to see changed. I shall list them for easy reading:


Pros:
-Looks very nice, the art style and graphics are well suited to the gameplay and concept
-Music and sound effects are appropriate for the situations you find them in and are original; No Wilhelm screams here
-Controls are simple, straight forward and respond well
-I really like the concept of starting at the top of the building and working your way down to the ground floor to get out. It's an interesting take in a game genre that usually involves you starting at ground floor and either going up a castle or down into a the dungeon. The idea of being trapped in a building full of windows is a cool twist.
-This game is difficult, but after you unlock a few perks and get familiar with the gameplay you can get further in each attempt, which is exactly how it should be.
-Crafting is solid and well thought out, there aren't many arbitrary items, everything you come across can be useful
-Enemies are well designed and all stand out from one another. You'll need a different strategy for each one which makes the combat a lot of fun

Cons:
-I've encountered a glitch where sometimes I will get a lot of artifacting. My computer doesn't quite have the grahical memory the game recommends, but I've played many other games where I don't meet the exact standards and the game runs just fine. Thankfully, the artifacting seems to only affect the background and if you have the interactable object indicator on, then the little eye symbol will show you which boxes of colour you can pick up. Strangely enough, even with this glitch the game is still 100% playable and is actually pretty funny; like playing on a SNES that's acting wonky.
-The accuracy seems to be a bit off. When I have an 80-85% chance to hit an enemy it seems a lot more like 70% from the amount of misses. That problem scales as well; at 50% chance only can hit an enemy 1 out of 3-4 times, which can truly screw you over. This should be looked at in the next few updates as it is the most annoying part of this otherwise great game.


TL;DR:

If you like RPGs, Rogue-likes, and crafting, then this game is right up your alley, I would highly recommend it.

reviewText:
SKYHILL is a kinda-zombie survival game with roguelike elements. You start at the top of the Skyhill building and have to fight and scourge your way through 99 floors back to possible safety.

VISUALS

Simple but solid 2d. I'm not too fond of the art style, but after a few hours I got used to the character model and enemies. The building itself, the rooms really, look quite allright and post-apocalypticsy. Intro and outro are made in a comic book way and are rather meh.

AUDIO

Simple and not annoying. The background music is plink plonking, the sound effects are very basic, but you don't need more. Nothing much to say here really.

GAMEPLAY

The premise is pretty simple, it's turn based, you can move one room at a time, each move costs food, food can be found. Each encountered enemy has to be killed if you want to pass through. You can find medpacks to heal, if your base is upgraded enough you can also heal by sleeping there. The base can be upgraded to allow for building new weapons, items or cooking better food. There is permadetah and the game can be very random, but that's not necessary bad. It's a roguelike after all.

All in all I had 10 or so hours of fun before I managed to get to the bottom for the first time. There are three endings, so there is some replayability. Recommended.

Summary:
The survival mechanics is why you'd want to play the game, as while the combat mechanics aren't anything to write home about, the rationing and risk/reward of attempting to find equipment does uniquely stand it apart from other games in the genre. It's hit a specific niche: if you like roguelikes and survival mechanics, this game may be up your alley, as it does that rather well. But that's if: if neither of those sound entirely interesting, then the games lackluster sound design and mechanics that could have gone a step further or two really won't make you play it in the long run, especially considering the repetitive nature of the runs. The lighting does stand out in the visual department, and I enjoyed my time with the game even when I'm not necessary a survival mechanic fan at times, but it's the home run hitter of the genre: if it connects with you: you'll be playing it for hours and hours. +:
Survival Mechanics work in terms of risk/reward: the idea being that when to use your assets and when not is vastly important, and each decision can become interesting in that way. Good mix of the roguelike mechanics here.

Difficulty levels are perfect in terms of providing little/ok/hard challenges and hit the sweet spot there for all kinds of players who want to play.

-:

Story integration lacks. Doesn't ever tie that well into the main gameplay, and feels seperated from what you are doing overall. Even elements that you pick up feel disjointed like it was pieced together.

Warning: This review is full of spoilers from someone who did not get spoilers ahead of time to know better.

If you're going to get this game, get it on sale. It's not that the game is bad, but that it simply too minimalistic, and I'm not talking about the art style--which is one of it's main good features. There's simply not that much to the game itself. It's a point and click roguelike game that admittedly tries but fails to achieve the basic aspects necessary regarding those two styles to make it worthwhile here. With the only options being to go down the stairs or to one of the two optional side rooms to ransack or kill the monster then ransack, it's too tedious to be enjoyable as a roguelike.

A point and click game needs strategy, which the option of where to hit monsters and what item you're going to smack them around with simply doesn't offer. But above all, it must have a good narrative. And that's what we're missing here, which is also quite possibly my biggest issue with the game, which is why it confused the hell out of me as to how this game got an award for it.

Spoiler alert: The initial narrative here is that you're stuck at the top of a building when nuclear war hits and the monsters start crawling out of the woodwork. You as the protagonist have to work your way to the ground floor while crafting tools to bludgeon things with or to fix the broken elevators/lights which inexplicably stopped working for all but the top five floors, and to cook up food because apparently you're an anemic who can't go from one room to another without suffering hunger pains for it. Not a bad premise in and of itself, but the execution is poorly handled.

The story can branch off in three different ways, but all are jumbled together in the course of the playthorugh that they contradict one another, and none actually contribute to the gameplay. From this, you get three potential endings, all of which are depressing and none of which are in any way original twists to include when they're all a few years past done to death". reviewText:
Verdict:
A shallow, uninspired and short lasting roguelike experience. Although pleasing at first, it falls flat with repetitiveness and strongly luck based gameplay. For the price, you’ll be much better off looking somewhere else to quench your roguelike thirst.

Score: 6/10

Full review:
With everlasting indie gaming boom and rising survival/roguelike trend, it’s no surprise developers are trying to apply some freshness to it. Skyhill is just that – a long shot. But let’s see where it failed and where it succeeded.

Starting the game, you’ll see what we call a tight budget. Reminding a Flash based browser game,  Skyhill keeps that convention. You’re welcomed with a short and lazily written story – being on a business trip, our protagonist does a little luxurious escapism in VIP room of Skyhill Hotel. Just then tragedy happens – a downpour of chemical weapons. Somehow you survived. The other inhabitants of hotel too but no longer in human form. And you’ve guessed it – it’s time to fight for your life.

Now, your objective is to descend to first floor and get out of this hellhole. Of course, it is not as easy as calling an elevator to get you straight to the exit door of Skyhill. Luckily, this roguelike is not THAT shallow. But learning quickly the ropes you’ll know what to expect soon enough. Quite honestly, it took me half an hour to realise that there won’t be anything besides what I saw in this short time.

The main flavor of Skyhill is crafting and fighting. The latter is a very simplified turn-based combat with possibility of choosing where you want to hit your enemy – giving more or less damage. Damage itself depends on your four stats. Each weapon is  bound to one or several stats. More points equals more damage. Overall, pretty basic, yet engaging.

Various mutated victims of chemical warfare aren’t your only adversaries. You’ll fight with every lifeform’s enemy – hunger. Any step you make in this 100 floor colossus takes away a portion of your hunger points. When it runs  down to zero, you start to lose health. Even when you take a snooze in your room to regain some of your hit points, your hunger grows. And it’s all about balance between wandering in hotel and keeping your hunger in check. You’ll find various items to keep you sated. Among others are weapons, meds, tools and supplies. With them you’ll be able to craft more nourishing meals, stronger weapons and improve facilities that provide better recipes and more effective, safer resting. Of course, it takes the right items to do that and you get them completely at random. Seemingly, luck is the main factor, balancing thrown out of the window.

Encountering enemies is scripted much better. They range from rather harmless zombies to notoriously hard, disfigured giant. The good thing is that you can die by any of them which induces some tension, keeping you from feeling safe. Sadly, you cannot expect the riskiness and excitement of exploring every nook and cranny or peeking to an unknown room. This is one of biggest offenders of Skyhill. Every floor is just a corridor with elevator door and two rooms. 15 minutes into a game and you know there will be no surprise. True, there are random events and snippets of story but they’re forgettable at best. This applies to whole presentation. Music, sounds and graphics are just unambitious. You’ll struggle to get into the mood but it’s more of you wanting it than you experiencing it.

Overall, I would lie that I didn’t enjoy playing It even with it’s shortcomings. I did enjoy it. But Skyhill is just too forgettable. I’ve managed to find the right tactics in matter of 2-3 hours along with lots of luck and finished it. After that, I didn’t feel any need or desire to come back and try higher difficulty. I’ve bought it for a fraction of it’s retail price. If I did pay it, I would feel cheated.
